Award.AwardTitle: Optimal tests for weak, sparse, and complex signals with application to genetic association studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Detection of sparse and weak signals is a key for analyzing big data in many fields. Recent statistical research has made celebrated theoretical progress in revealing the detectability boundaries under the Gaussian means model and an idealized linear regression model. Detectability boundary illustrates the border in the two-dimensional phase space of signal sparsity and weakness, below which the signals are asymptotically too weak and sparse to be detectable by any statistical methods. Certain statistics are optimal for these models in the sense that they reach the boundary (i.e., the least requirements) for reliable signal detection. However, there are significant gaps between these theoretical models and practical meaningful models. In this project, the investigators extend statistical theory to handle weak, sparse, correlated, and interactive signals under the framework of generalized linear models. The investigators develop optimal testing procedures to address the realistic data features in genome-wide association studies and next-generation sequence studies.

Statistical theory and methodology development for the detection of weak and sparse signals is foundational for analyzing big data. The goal of this project is to extend statistical theoretical study to address complex signals that are correlated and interactively influential to quantitative or categorical responses. This study is of great interest in data science and is critical to many applications. For example, one perplexing problem of current genetic studies is the missing heritability of complex traits even after many genetic factors have been identified. The proposed work specifically addresses the features of those hidden disease genes yet to be discovered. Unlike some genetic studies based on heuristic arguments, this research combines the power of rigorous statistical theory, first-hand practices in the field, and cutting-edge data from genome-wide association studies and next-generation sequence studies. The proposed project is highly promising in the hunt for the missing heritability. Highly improved gene-detection techniques will help to identify more causative genes of complex human diseases, which will lead to the elucidation of disease pathogenesis and design of targeted therapeutics, thus have a far-reaching impact on improving quality of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major Activities:

Major activies include mathematical statistical research in signal detection theory, design of test statistics optimal for identifying weak, sparse, and complex genetic effects, computational implementation in R, real data analysis and new putative gene discovery, paper writing and publication, supporting student and educational programs, conference attending, etc.  

Specific Objectives:

Objective 1: Reveal the detectability boundary and develop the optimal tests for correlated signals based on linear model setup for quantitative traits. Commonly used tests are shown suboptimal.

Objective 2: Reveal the detectability boundary and develop the optimal tests for correlated covariates and unknown error variance. Detection boundaries are revealed under this more realistic setup. More importantly, we develop analytical calculations for p-value and statistical power under finite $n$.

Objective 3: Develop the optimal tests for signals characterized by generalized linear models. We focus on the logistic model and study both marginal and the joint association tests.

Objective 4: Apply and assess the methodology in real GWAS and NGS data analysis and develop software. Thee optimal tests are applied and assessed in the analysis of GWAS and exome sequencing
data of ALS. R package are programmed for biomedical researchers. A list of promising candidate 
genes are detected.

Significant Results:

We extended the theoretical group-testing research to address sparse, weak and complex signals under a generalized linear model setup with application to GWAS and NGS. First, we revealed the detectability boundaries for signals of correlated and interactive covariates. These boundaries essentially indicate the limit of statistical analysis: signals that below the boundaries are simply too rare and weak to be reliable detected by any statistical methods. Based on the boundary, wevcan tell whether a test is optimal according to whether it works for thevminimally detectable signals. Second, we developed optimal tests and applied to real GWAS and exome sequencing data of Crohn's diease and amyotrophic lateralvsclerosis (ALS). A few putative genes were discovered. Third, we implemented computational tools for scientists to apply these methods in real data analysis. 

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

We published a series of research papers that reported the results on theory and methodology in statistical signal detection. These results are particularly important for scientific society to understand the mechanisim for how genetic effects are revealed by data-evidenced signals and thus detected by statistical algorithms, especially when signals are weak, sparse, and correlated. We resolved important problems that were obstacle to applying optimal signal detection statistics in real data analaysis. These results were also applied into real studies of Crohn's disease and ALS, and produced a few putative disease genes, some of them were biologically validated. We also provided R functios and packages for implementation of these statistical algorithms. The results were disseminated through seminars and presentations in professional conferences. The research project itself and relevant products also helped relevant course teaching and educational programs.
